1. Introduction and Motivation

The determinant is an important characteristic for square matrices, which, among other things, provides information about the invertibility of a matrix and plays a central role in many applications of linear algebra.

What is a Determinant?

A determinant is a function that assigns a number to each square matrix. It provides important information about the matrix and its properties.

2. Definition and Properties

Formal Definition

The determinant of an n√ón matrix A = a·µ¢‚±º is defined as:

$$\det(A) = \sum_{\sigma \in S_n} \text{sgn}(\sigma) \prod_{i=1}^n a_{i,\sigma(i)}$$

where S‚Çô is the symmetric group and sgn(œÉ) is the sign of the permutation œÉ.

Important Properties

1. Multiplicativity

$$\det(AB) = \det(A) \cdot \det(B)$$

The determinant of the product of two matrices is equal to the product of their determinants.

2. Transpose

$$\det(A^T) = \det(A)$$

The determinant of a matrix is equal to the determinant of its transpose.

3. Row and Column Operations

  • Swapping two rows/columns changes the sign
  • Multiplying a row/column by a scalar multiplies the determinant by that scalar
  • Adding a multiple of one row/column to another does not change the determinant

4. Invertibility

$$\det(A) \neq 0 \Leftrightarrow A \text{ is invertible}$$

A matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is non-zero.

3. Calculating Determinants

3.1 Determinant of a 2√ó2 Matrix

For a 2√ó2 matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$$

the determinant is:

$$\det(A) = ad - bc$$

Example

Calculate the determinant of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

$$\det(A) = 2 \cdot 5 - 3 \cdot 4 = 10 - 12 = -2$$

3.2 Determinant of a 3√ó3 Matrix (Sarrus Rule)

For a 3√ó3 matrix:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix}$$

the determinant is:

$$\det(A) = aei + bfg + cdh - ceg - afh - bdi$$

Example

Calculate the determinant of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

$$\det(A) = 1 \cdot 5 \cdot 9 + 2 \cdot 6 \cdot 7 + 3 \cdot 4 \cdot 8 - 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 - 1 \cdot 6 \cdot 8 - 2 \cdot 4 \cdot 9$$

$$= 45 + 84 + 96 - 105 - 48 - 72 = 0$$

3.3 Expansion by a Row or Column (Laplace Expansion)

For an n√ón matrix A:

$$\det(A) = \sum_{j=1}^n (-1)^{i+j} a_{ij} \det(A_{ij})$$

where A·µ¢‚±º is the (n-1)√ó(n-1) matrix obtained by deleting the i-th row and j-th column.

Example

Calculate the determinant of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution by expanding along the first row:

$$\det(A) = 2 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} - 1 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 0 & 5 \\ 1 & 3 \end{vmatrix} + 3 \cdot \begin{vmatrix} 0 & 4 \\ 1 & 2 \end{vmatrix}$$

$$= 2(12 - 10) - 1(0 - 5) + 3(0 - 4) = 4 + 5 - 12 = -3$$

3.4 Gaussian Elimination

By elementary row operations, the matrix can be brought into triangular form. The determinant is then the product of the diagonal elements.

Example

Calculate the determinant of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 5 & 7 \\ 3 & 7 & 11 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

1. Subtract 2 times the first row from the second row:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 3 & 7 & 11 \end{pmatrix}$$

2. Subtract 3 times the first row from the third row:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$$

3. Subtract the second row from the third row:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

4. The determinant is the product of the diagonal elements:

$$\det(A) = 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 = 1$$

4. Special Determinants

4.1 Diagonal Matrix

For a diagonal matrix D = diag(d‚ÇÅ, d‚ÇÇ, ..., d‚Çô):

$$\det(D) = \prod_{i=1}^n d_i$$

Example

$$\det\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 4 = 24$$

4.2 Triangular Matrix

For an upper or lower triangular matrix T:

$$\det(T) = \prod_{i=1}^n t_{ii}$$

Example

$$\det\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 \\ 0 & 0 & 6 \end{pmatrix} = 1 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 = 24$$

4.3 Vandermonde Determinant

For the Vandermonde matrix V(x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ, ..., x‚Çô):

$$\det(V) = \prod_{1 \leq i < j \leq n} (x_j - x_i)$$

Example

For n = 3:

$$\det\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ x_1 & x_2 & x_3 \\ x_1^2 & x_2^2 & x_3^2 \end{pmatrix} = (x_2 - x_1)(x_3 - x_1)(x_3 - x_2)$$

5. Applications

5.1 Invertibility

A matrix A is invertible if and only if det(A) ‚â† 0.

Example

Examine the invertibility of:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 6 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

$$\det(A) = 1 \cdot 6 - 2 \cdot 3 = 0$$

The matrix is not invertible since det(A) = 0.

5.2 Volume Calculation

The determinant of a matrix gives the volume of the parallelepiped spanned by the column vectors.

Example

Calculate the volume of the parallelepiped spanned by the vectors:

$$\vec{v}_1 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \vec{v}_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \vec{v}_3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$$

Solution:

$$V = \left|\det\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\right| = 1$$

5.3 Cramer's Rule

The solution of a linear system of equations Ax = b can be calculated using determinants:

$$x_i = \frac{\det(A_i)}{\det(A)}$$

where A·µ¢ is the matrix obtained by replacing the i-th column of A with b.

Example

Solve the system of equations:

$$\begin{cases} 2x + y = 5 \\ x + 3y = 7 \end{cases}$$

Solution:

$$A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}, \vec{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 7 \end{pmatrix}$$

$$\det(A) = 5, \det(A_1) = 8, \det(A_2) = 9$$

$$x = \frac{8}{5}, y = \frac{9}{5}$$

6. Summary

Determinants are important characteristics of square matrices with diverse applications in linear algebra.

Important Properties:

  • Multiplicativity
  • Invariance under transposition
  • Behavior under row and column operations
  • Relationship with invertibility

Calculation Methods:

  • 2√ó2 Matrix: ad - bc
  • 3√ó3 Matrix: Sarrus Rule
  • Laplace Expansion
  • Gaussian Elimination

Applications:

  • Invertibility of matrices
  • Volume calculation
  • Solving linear systems of equations
  • Eigenvalue calculation
